channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Mt Eden bones mystery: Police identify body
item.description: Police have identified a body found entombed in concrete at a Mt Eden home in January.

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates from NZ and around the world on 4 September
item.description: The country will find out today whether or not the government will ease alert level restrictions and public transport operators must now display QR codes. Follow RNZ's blog for the latest.

item.title: Missing cattle export ship: Rescue efforts to continue amid second typhoon
item.description: Another typhoon is expected to hit the region where a cattle export ship has gone missing with dozens of crew members, including two New Zealanders, in the East China Sea.

item.title: A decade since the quake that started it all
item.description: It is billed as the earthquake that started it all, it was magnitude 7.1 and it hit 10km from the Canterbury town of Darfield at 4.35am on 4 September 2010.

item.title: Some GP clinics close as primary care nurses and admin staff strike
item.description: Strike action by about 3200 primary care nurses and administration staff yesterday affected about 500 GP clinics and accident and medical centres nationwide, forcing some to close for the day.

item.title: Earthquake anniversary marks 10 years of disruption
item.description: The Detail - It's 10 years to the day since the first big Christchurch earthquake - and now a generation of children as familiar with liquefaction as they are with literature are reaching the end of their high school years.

item.title: Invercargill City Council estimates addressing concerns raised by govt review could cost $70,000
item.description: The Invercargill City Council's plans to restore trust and confidence in its ability to govern is likely to cost ratepayers tens of thousands of dollars.

item.title: Strong magnitude 5.7 earthquake hits top of South Island
item.description: A magnitude 5.7 earthquake has struck the top of the South Island.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 3 September
item.description: There were two new cases of Covid-19 announced on Thursday, New Zealand Steel may have to axe up to 200 employees and fewer coronavirus patients die when given steroids, a new study has found.

item.title: New Zealand young people facing 'silent pandemic of psychological distress'
item.description: Mental health conditions amongst young people have doubled in the past decade with researchers describing it as "a silent pandemic of psychological distress".

item.title: Live cattle exports suspended after ship goes missing - MPI
item.description: The Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) has temporarily suspended consideration of cattle livestock export applications.

item.title: Auckland school rolls remain low despite government pleas
item.description: School rolls in Auckland continue to languish, despite urging from the Education Minister to get children back into classrooms.

item.title: PSA union takes legal action against Access Community Health
item.description: A union is taking legal action against a community health company saying it has failed to give staff their entitled breaks and correct pay for more than a year.

item.title: Support groups call for action following NZ's poor showing in Unicef child wellbeing ratings
item.description: The Prime Minister wants New Zealand to be the best place in the world to grow up - but Unicef's latest child wellbeing rankings have the country among the worst performing in the developed world.

item.title: CAA: 'Amateur built' plane broke apart in mid-air at excess speed
item.description: The "amateur built" kitset single engine aircraft was being flown from Whangārei to Dargaville on New Year's Day, 2018.

item.title: Internet users need to be savvy about political memes - expert
item.description: An expert in political satire says memes can be an incredibly powerful tool to add to debate, but internet users need to be savvy about where they come from and what kind of message they're pushing.

item.title: Darfield War Memorial to be illuminated ahead of 10th anniversary of Canterbury earthquake
item.description: The Darfield War Memorial will be lit up tonight ahead of the 10-year anniversary of the 7.2 magnitude earthquake that struck nearby, causing widespread damage around Canterbury.

item.title: Canterbury DHB confirms part of new hospital will not open due to lack of funds
item.description: A Canterbury Māori health leader is outraged the region's deficit-laden DHB has built a new emergency care unit for children but cannot afford to staff it.
